results.description:
Contact:   Mike Clancy  [masked]

Spots are limited as the park has set a group limit.   It's 15 now but I may be able to add a couple more spots later in the week. Please be sure you can attend before signing up.


The leaves are ready to change color at the e beautiful Sam's Point area of Minnewaska State Park. The park is at the south end of the Shawangunk Ridge off State Route 52 in Cragsmoor, NY.   The Visitor's Center opens and 9AM.  Parking fee is $10/car.  There is some great information/videos at the park web site:  http://www.nysparks.com/parks/193/details.aspx

On the holiday weekend the lot is expected to fill quickly so please arrive on time. We will start from the Visitor's Center and basically follow the Shawangunk Ridge Trail (SRT) to the 150+ feet Verkeerder Kill Falls where we will break for lunch. On the way to the falls, we will take a detour to explore the interesting features of the Ice Caves. 

Start time:  9:15 AM                     Duration: Approx 5 hrs

Distance:  Approx. 7 miles         Difficulty:  Moderate

Elev. Gain: Approx 600'

Gear:  proper footwear, clothing for changing temps, headlamp or light, water,               snacks/lunch

                                                         ***********

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
This is a workshop that helps us live the Conservationist's Way - Nurturing ourselves so that we can nurture not just human nature, but all of nature. 

Registration is now open. To register (which is required) click here.  

General information follows:

Nurturing Nature: Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth’s

A workshop that helps us live compassionately, joyfully, and healthy in a multispecies world

As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us. We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves. One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. This Nurture Nature Workshop...

-Seeks to remedy that situation by inviting participants to a lifelong discovery of nature accompanied by practice and discipline that that will provide resources and resilience for living compassionately. By accepting our own inner animal, our compassion spreads outrageously beyond kin and kind to all of life.
-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.
- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth. These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices.
- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister. She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species. Currently she serves life as the Director of One Earth Conservation and Ministry, facilitating learning and practice communities such as this workshop and also collaborating on multiple teams throughout Latin America that seek to heal our biotic communities through incorporating the human dimension in parrot conservation.

results.description:
LEADER:  Debbie Bell ([masked] or <a>[masked]</a> (NCA 9 PM))

RATING:  C 5 C

Meet at Iona Island parking area on Rt. 9W, south of Bear Mountain Inn, at 9:30 AM.  We will walk on old carriage trails and country lanes in historic Doodletown.  Doodletown was first occupied by French Huguenot settlers in the 1700s, and at one time boasted 350 residents.  It was acquired by the Palisades Park Commission in the 1900s and, as the occupants left, or were removed by eminent domain, the buildings were destroyed.  Today we see only foundations and signs.  The terrain has some ups and downs, but we will go at a leisurely pace.  All hikers who want a relaxed day in the woods are welcome.  Please wear appropriate footwear for unpaved trails, and bring lunch and water.  Register with the leader (above) in case there are last-minute changes because of weather or other developments.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

Esposito Memorial Trail. After leaving the rail-trails, a short road bike along Broadway will bring us to Nyack Beach State Park where we will bike along the Hudson River just under Hook Mountain. results.description:
This experiential workshop helps us develop nature spiritual practices so that we nurture not just ourselves, but all of nature.

Registration is now open, and required. Wainwright House in Rye is handling the registration. Click here to register.

General information follows:

Nurturing Nature:  Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth’s


A workshop that helps us live compassionately, joyfully, and healthy in a multispecies world

As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us.  We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves.  One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. 

This Nurture Nature Workshop...

-Seeks to remedy that situation by inviting participants to a lifelong discovery of nature accompanied by practice and discipline that that will provide resources and resilience for living compassionately.  By accepting our own inner animal, our compassion spreads outrageously beyond kin and kind to all of life. 

-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.

- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth.  These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices. 

- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister.  She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species.  Currently she serves life as the Director of One Earth Conservation and Ministry, facilitating learning and practice communities such as this workshop and also collaborating on multiple teams throughout Latin America that seek to heal our biotic communities through incorporating the human dimension in parrot conservation.

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Conference on Modern Cosmism on October 10 in New York Society for Ethical Culture.

The conference will address important philosophical, ethical and technology issues that arise in the design of artificial consciousness, artificial intelligence and mind uploading. Will we be able to create super intelligent agents with consciousness and feelings? What are the limits of artificial capacities or functional simulations, we should create? Could we enhance our own humanity ?

Please register here : http://www.cosmism.com/events.html

Conference Description: Cosmism was originated in Russia more than a hundred years ago. That was an esoteric futuristic philosophy about post-humanity, technological immortality, resurrection and cosmic expansion. Early cosmists proposed the idea of decompaction (lightweighting) of the human body, that eventually wouldn’t need an atmosphere and would be powered directly by solar energy. They call it “radiant humanity” - a perfect society of highly moral and super-conscious beings merging and colonizing the whole Universe. Modern Cosmism brings to the original doctrine the ontological foundation, a scientific structure and a deeper comprehension of possible technology aims to create in the future a new synthetic reality where the concepts of truth, consciousness, freedom and happiness will be deeply revised. The conference will review the critical question about a potential meeting with advanced extraterrestrial civilizations and suggest few hypotheses about their “eerie silence”. We will touch some related problems in cosmology, and astrophysics such as the shape and future of the Universe, black hole information paradox, multidimensional space, dark energy and interpretation of quantum mechanics. Are they a separate arrow of time? Are there exceptions to the principle of causality? Like no other area of philosophy and technology before, Modern Cosmism raises fundamental questions about the post human nature and how it will be connected to the reality. Is the structure of reality included the consciousness? Is a non biological hardware can support the consciousness? How we can define Cosmic Evolution and what is the role of intelligent life? The conference will address important philosophical issues that arise with the future design of artificial consciousness, mind uploading and cyber-immortality. How will our concepts of subjectivity, perception, and morality change, if we will live in virtual reality of mega-consciousness environment where individuals can experience multiple presence, personality and have no gender. Will we be able to create super intelligent agents with consciousness and feelings? What are the limits of artificial capacities or functional simulations we should create? Could we enhance our own humanity by genetically redesign our nature? Our keynote and plenary speakers are well-known international protagonists of Cosmism, Transhumanism and interdisciplinary researchers. Their lectures will discuss the most important current issues of Modern Cosmism from the point of view of philosophy, technology, ethics, robotics, psychology, and anthropology.

results.description:
Curious about web development? Read about it online, or done some introductory courses on Codecademy? Want to learn more, face-to-face with others in a welcoming community?

Join us to dive into “full stack web development” and learn about the full stack from the front end to the back end. In this full-day workshop, we’ll collectively work through each of the three introductory topics from our Beginner series: 

</a>

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/DBC-NYC/events/224449450/">HTML/CSS for Beginners - evening workshop [9/29 from 6:30-9pm] 
Javascript for Beginners - evening workshop [10/1 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Ruby for Beginners - evening workshop [10/6 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Full Stack Development - day long weekend workshop [10/10 from 10am-6pm]


</a>

All of these elements combine to make the World Wide Web go ‘round! Specifically, we’ll cover:

* All the tools you need to get up, running and coding with HTML, CSS, Ruby and JavaScript

* Building and styling a basic webpage with HTML and CSS

* Basic programming concepts like variables, loops, functions, strings, arrays and objects

* How to write these things in JavaScript and Ruby
Interacting with the HTML and CSS of a webpage using JavaScript

* Setting up a simple web server using Ruby and sending HTML pages to a browser

* The basics of interacting with a third party API (the Twitter API in this workshop)

• Available resources if you’d like to continue learning 

Prerequisite: A basic understanding of HTML/CSS, JavaScript and Ruby (e.g. topics covered in Codecademy’s <a href="https://www.codecademy.com/tracks/web">HTML/CSS, JavaScript and Ruby<a href="https://www.codecademy.com/tracks/javascript"></a> tracks).


This event is open to adult (18+) beginners and is an introduction to concepts covered more deeply in the immersive program. Please bring your own laptop (Mac-preferred). Lunch will be provided.
results.name: Full Stack Web Development: What you can build in a day

results.description:
Looking for a way to welcome in Fall with the family?  This event is old fashioned family fun.  Pumpkin carving and hayrides.  Children's activities and puppet shows.  (If you've never seen a Waldorf puppet show, you're in for a treat!)

Delicious healthy food, great music and many stalls of unique hand crafted gifts, classic hand made toys and clothing.  Great for early Christmas shopping if you're looking for something beautiful and unique.

This will be our second year attending and it always delights our children.  So much to do, it's hard to fit it all in.  So please do join in the fun.  Set in the leafy grounds of the school, this is the heart of an alternative community that holds many of the same values dear as our Attachment parenting community.  Thousands attend each year!

A really memorable Family day out.  Free Admission and Parking.

Online registration is only $15 Event day registration will be $25 Children under 18 are FREE! Guest Speaker: Gene Baur, Farm Sanctuary's President and Co-Founder Guest Speaker: Jasmin Singer, Our Hen House's Executive Director  Walk Details:

Central Park (Naumburg Bandshell)
October 10, 2015
Check-in: 10 AM
Walk: 11 AM - 1:30 PM

Directions and Parking: Will be available soon! 

If you've walked before, please note the new location. I'm unfamiliar with this area of the park, so I'm not sure where we should meet. I'll email participants my phone number before the walk to make it easier for us to find each other.


For more details, visit the Walk For Farm Sanctuary website:  http://walkforfarmanimals.org/

venue.name: State Line Lookout

results.description:
Come join Bergen/Hudson for an early autumn hike along the Palisades! 

We will be meeting at the Palisades State Line Lookout Point and then will move forward with a moderately challenging hike that features phenomenal views, waterfalls, and historic ruins. 

The hike is 3 miles round trip and should take about 2-2.5 hours. Afterwards, for all that are interested, we will be getting lunch at a location to be decided. 

Bring water, sturdy shoes, and appropriate clothing. As a bonus, you can also bring your dog! Only requirement is that it be on a leash at all times. 

Rain Date - Saturday Oct 10, 2015.

Directions:
State Line Lookout is about a mile south of the actual New Jersey–New York state line. It has its own (unnumbered) exit in Alpine, New Jersey, about 2 miles north of Palisades Interstate Parkway Exit 2, accessible directly from the PIP northbound lanes and via a median U-turn from the PIP southbound lanes, and is also accessible to hikers on the Long Path and to pedestrians and cyclists via Old Route 9W.

From northbound Palisades Interstate Parkway: The well-marked exit for State Line Lookout is about 2 mi. north of Exit 2.

From southbound Palisades Interstate Parkway: Stay in the left lane after passing Exit 3. Take the median U-turn (well marked). Use caution, as you will need to get into the right lane immediately to exit for State Line Lookout.
results.name: Hiking Along The Palisades

results.description:
Join us on Saturday, October 10, 2015 at 10:00 a.m. to hear Mark Glogowski, newly elected LPNY Chair, speak to us about his goals for the Libertarian Party of New York. Joining him will be Jim Rosenbeck, newly elected LPNY Vice-Chair, who has been very active with respect to chapter development. He will bring us up to date with respect to his activities. Both will join us for lunch at noon as our guest. The event will take place in the Library of the Queens Pride House located at[masked]th Avenue, Suite 206, Jackson Heights, New York 11372.


ADMISSION FEE: $3.00 for Queens LP members; $5.00 for Non-Members.

If you are driving, arrive early to look for free street parking. There are also many 2-hour Muni-Meter spots and a nearby parking lot.

If you are coming by subway, use the IRT "7" Flushing Line and exit at 74th Street/Broadway. You can also use the IND "E", "F" or "R" Queens Blvd. Lines and exit at the Jackson Heights/Roosevelt Avenue stop.

If you get lost, call Dr. Tom Stevens on his cell phone at[masked]-7075.

================

Before being elected LPNY Chair, Mark Glogowski published the following statement regarding the goals he would seek to achieve if elected:

1) I believe we are a political party, not an activist group. While we can support activist groups, this party should not be focused on changing the vote on a bill, but rather changing individuals who are going to change the vote on a bill. 

2) A group defines itself by identifying who is part of their group and w ho is not.  If we welcome everyone from every political party to be actively involved in defining what it is we stand for - well, we probably don't really stand for anything - have a cup of tea. 

3) The Libertarian party has embraced, or at least I believe it embraced, the unique political philosophy that led to the creation of the Declaration of Independence and the US Constitution. [I refer to that philosophy as the Advocate Worldview.]  The Declaration of Independence could have been written by anyone of any political persuasion. However, the US Constitution could only have been formulated by people who embraced the Advocate Worldview. They put their lives on the line to create a Libertarian (Advocate)structure for our society. What does that mean? It means a society where government reports to you, you do not report to the government; it means a government that receives funds because you want to part with them, not a government that 'taxes' them from you, where 'taxes' is equivalent to take; it means a government that does not intrude on your life; it means a government that is naturally fiscally small; it means a government that answers to those who empower government, not empower the people who answer to government. 

4) Yes, I believe we should be an exclusive club. You cannot embrace two political philosophies at the same time (and I would be willing to elaborate and demonstrate this to anyone who doubts that fact): While everyone can join the Tea Party regardless of what they believe, the Libertarian Party is suppose to be a party comprised of, and consisting of, individuals who have proudly stood up and said they support the Libertarian (Advocate) political philosophy and that they want that political philosophy exclusively used to create our laws.  Until a person is willing to make this statement publicly, I say let them remain outside until they decide for themselves who they want to support. Politics is not a game. It is an alternative to war, and not many people choose to fight on all sides in a war.  [Interestingly, there were four sides in WWII. Three sides joined forces against the fourth. There are also four sides in politics.] 

5) We do a lot of complaining about the two party system. Yet, with our current inclusive approach to membership we support the two party system. What is the definition of hypocrisy? We should be putting out a loud call for those voters on the side lines to stand up (about 72% in the district I ran in) and join us, and for the voters registered i n the other political parties to leave those parties and to join us. And this is why we are not growing as a political party: The voters don't have to re-register; we are not an exclusive club.  

6) "They also serve who only stand to be counted". Only the individual can decide what it is they believe and what it is they want to tell the world to believe. No other individual, and no group, can do this for the individual. No matter how much effort and no matter how much money a person throws at the NYLP, if the person remains affiliated publicly with another party, it is because it is the other party that they truly want to influence and support. To them I would just say, best of luck. 

7) If inclusivity is good, w e should start a campaign that goes something like: "Join the Libertarian party: You don't even have to register Libertarian because our State Committee is more than 75% non-Libertarian registered voters. 

Mark G.
results.name: Mark Glogowski (LPNY Chair) & Jim Rosenbeck (LPNY Vice-Chair)

results.description:
Hi Everyone,

NYU has approached me regarding a research they are running with cyclists, and they said our group would be a great candidate for it!

Best of all, half of the participants will receive free membership to Swerve cycling studio for 3 month (a $1080 value), while the other half (the control group) will come in to play video games but will also be compensated monetarily and also get free 12 classes at Swerve ($360 value).

I think this would be a great opportunity to do some studio team cycling, in days like today when the weather doesn't agree with us.

In order to participate, RSVP to the event and I will get you in touch with the research coordinator who will sign you up.

Feel free to contact me with any questions.

I will be going, and hope to see many of you as well.

Here is the description from the research team:

Exercise group gets free cycling classes (3 times a week for 3 months) at SWERVE Fitness - a value of $1080. 
Video game group gets 12 free classes after 3 months of participating in the study (a $360 value). 

Both groups will receive $30 each for a pre- and post-intervention session, for a total of $60.

Happy weekend,

Aviv
results.name: Free Cycling Classes at Swerve!!! ($1080 value)

results.description:
Meetup/Hangout – 9:45 am

Whole Foods (Union Square) -- upstairs cafe. Show up a bit early to say hi, chat, and drop off any thing you don’t want to run with: jackets, bags, phones, etc. Somebody will always stay to watch the stuff.

Run – 10:00 am

Run 1 mile, 3 miles, 5 miles, or whatever you want. We'll head to the West Side Highway together. No pressure and no limits. Totally informal. Lots of different paces for lots of different people. Even walking speed is encouraged!

Brunch – 10:45 am

Whole Foods has ALL THE FOOD. Come get some.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

results.description: It's still nice and fairly warm, so let's get outside: Let's start at the top of Manhattan at Dyckman fields, and head down the west side! We'll run/jog down alongside the hudson until we reach Pier i cafe at 66th street! (they're open until mid October so this is the last chance of the season) Along the way we'll play with whatever we find for natural movement: lifting logs, throwing, climbing, crawling, balancing… I find that mixing up our movements is the best way to keep fresh in longer distance runs! from dyckman to the pier i is just over 7 miles, and from there we can grab a beer and lunch… (and if anyone is really ambitious, just keep going to the statue of liberty) Who's game?

Note:  due to inclement weather, we rescheduled this hike to October 10.

Join us at this fun-filled Bear Mountain hike with Oktoberfest celebration on Saturday, October 3. This twelve-and-a-half-mile hike is rather strenuous and fast-paced and consists of about a mile of rock scrambling, steep climbs and declines and approximately 2,740 feet of elevation gain (AMC Hike rating 4D12.5). If you're up for the challenge, you'll be rewarded with spectacular views of the Hudson River and Hudson Valley across the river… and better yet, Oktoberfest!

YOU MUST EMAIL THE HIKE LEADERS IN ORDER TO REGISTER FOR THIS HIKE. Click the link for hike details and registration instructions:  http://bit.ly/1VyfsNS

results.description:
FSG 2.0: Contracts, Work Agreements, and Proposals—Oh My!


Ah, the dreaded contracts. Definitely not a favorite task, but an important one! Independent workers commonly deal with unnecessary time management conflicts and payment discrepancies due to contract confusion.

For our next meetup, we’ll share our insights about work agreements and exchange contract content. We will also discuss work agreement components including project proposals, work statements, and contracts with clearly defined scopes of work. Together, we’ll learn how to create our own contracts for a seamless work experience.

Bring any existing templates you may have (minus proprietary & private information) and come hungry. Brunch will be provided!

If you'd like to stick around after brunch and work for a few hours, we will have a special open coworking session from 12:30pm - 4pm.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

This group is open to Freelancers, Consultants, Independent Contract Workers, and anyone who wants to transition into self-employment. We will share resources, war-stories, and other personal experiences, in an effort to provide solutions to the many challenges of working independently. Topics of conversation will vary at each meetup.

Topic Examples:

How much should I charge for my services?

How do I deal with a client that won't pay? 

What is the best way to create a portfolio to show my work?

How do I negotiate a contract?

We will try to meet at least once a month. If you have recommendations and/or location requests, let us know and we will try our best to accommodate. If you have any suggestions, ideas, feedback, requests, etc., please share below!

Freelancer Support Group is the brainchild of Lara Schenck, Independent Web Consultant & Educator.

If you have any suggestions, ideas, feedback, requests...please share HERE!
results.name: Freelancer Support Group 2.0: Contracts, Work Agreements, & Proposals—Oh My!

As featured in the NY Times (8/2/15) and the Journal News (8/10/15)!!!  Due to the popularity of yoga classes in breweries, Captain Lawrence is adding additional classes to their schedule.

The yoga class will be led by Lauren:

http://www.westchesteryogini.com/

Saturday, October 10, 2015, 10:30 AM- 12:30 PM +. Captain Lawrence Brewery in Elmsford, New York.

Best way to get there- turn onto Executive Boulevard from the light at 9A.  Then turn left onto Clearbrook Road.  The brewery is the first driveway on your left.  Go into the tasting room near the picket fence on the left.

Yoga and Beer. Join us for a morning yoga practice followed by beer packed with antioxidants that will compliment our asana practice.  We will practice in the brewery before it opens; followed up with beer samples.  (We have about a half hour after the class to sample unlimited amounts of five or six different varieties of beer).  Since the yoga is inside the brewery, the event will be held, rain or shine.  Feel free to stay and make the day of it.  Hang out at the brewery, grab a bite to eat (pizza from Gleason’s of Peekskill Mobile Wood Fired Pizza Oven), and play bocce outside.  There is usually live music on Saturdays- The Bottoms Up Dixieland Jazz Band plays from 2 - 5.

$25- includes yoga, tasting glass and featured beers.

Don't believe beer and yoga mix? Read.....

http://www.yogajournal.com/practice-section/beer-can-enhance-practice/

For information on Captain Lawrence, see:

http://www.captainlawrencebrewing.com/

Please bring your own yoga stuff- mat, block, towel, strap, water, etc. (The brewery has some Lululemon mats- I recommend you use them for additional padding).  Sunscreen if you want to hang out outside afterwards.

Come out and enjoy a good stretch with your fellow hikers!

Liability Waiver: Yoga, like all physical activities, has inherent risks. Your participation in our hikes, yoga classes or other events could be dangerous and can result in serious injury, medical emergency, even death. You agree to participate in this event completely at your own risk and to take full responsibility for your own safety and well being, including those of your guests. By joining this meetup, you acknowledge that you are physically able to participate.

Warning: This is a real Yoga class!!!

Remember: Do not drink and drive. If you are going to drink, make sure you have a designated driver.

results.description:
"Picasso Sculpture" is a sweeping survey of Pablo Picasso’s innovative and influential work in three dimensions. This is the first such museum exhibition in the United States in nearly half a century.

Let's start by meeting at Starbucks, to introduce ourselves over coffee.

Then we'll go over to MOMA, to see the Picasso Sculpture show.  See Roberta Smith's glowing review in the NY Times:


http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/arts/design/review-picasso-sculpture-moma-museum-of-modern-art.html?_r=0

I'm hoping we can more or less synchronize our viewing pace, so that we can see--and share--and comment on--this exhibit. 


FYI, the exhibit is large...it takes up a whole floor.


Attendees are responsible for paying for any purchases from Starbucks, and for the special $5 guest rate to enter MOMA on my membership pass.  That's right, you will save $20 vs. the normal $25 admission price! 


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet inside Starbucks at 1290 Sixth Ave, entrance on 52nd St, between 5th & 6th Ave.  I will display a red Meetup sign.
results.name: Connect by Seeing the Amazing "Picasso Sculpture" Show at MOMA

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Take Acoustic Guitar Lessons in Central Park
Free Group Lessons Saturdays, May 16th to October 17.


You will learn to read notes, chords and play songs you know and love.  You will have the opportunity to learn:

results.description:
Hiking and Oktoberfest beers - what more could you ask for?  For the hike, we'll be scaling up to Anthony's Nose via the Camp Smith/blue blazed trail south of the Bear Mountain Bridge on Rt. 202/6. GPS coordinates for our starting point are[masked], -73.951256. The hike boast several great viewpoints and some nice inclines to scale. For details on the hike, check out the link from the NYNJTC and this one by a local hiker. This a round trip hike to/fro the same trail, approximately 6 miles round trip however we'll discuss the day of the hike if we have some cars park at the northern exit of the trail instead.

Afterwards, we'll stop by Peekskill Brewery and sample their Fall beer selection.


As with most hikes on this meetup, this is a new trail for the organizer and perhaps yourself. We'll be following the trail map, research on the trail (noted above) and our own sense of direction. Marked trails are easy enough to follow but at times you might deviate down an incorrect path. You'll be expected to be prepared and involved in any decisions made on trail routes, etc. Lastly, we're here to enjoy the day, the sights and get some exercise.


Miles: Approximately 6 miles

Difficulty: Intermediate - If you're a true beginner it will be a challenge but doable. If you're a bit more experienced, know that we'll be going at a leisurely pace; we go as fast as the slowest person on the trip. This is appropriate for anyone just looking to enjoy a hike.

Recommended Equipment

You're expected to be prepared and have all appropriate day hiking gear for this trip however at minimum you should have the following:

Sturdy hiking boots 2 1L bottles of water or camel back Lunch/snacks Trail map: NY/NJ TC#1 or 101 (optional) Transportation

Car: We will carpool and passengers pick up the tabs on gas/tolls. Please post if you need a ride or can give a ride. Drivers please post on your RSVP state from where and how many passengers you can take.

Train: You can take the Metro North train to Peekskill and cab it to the trail starting point (about 2.5 miles away). You should catch the train leaving Grand Central that gets you there by 11am. Round trip fare is around $24/pp. For more details, check out this link fro recommended transportation info.

Disclaimer: You agree when you sign up that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. Your attendance to an event signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. The complete liability waiver can be found on the PAGES section of this meetup site.
results.name: Anthony's Nose / Peekskill Brewery

results.description:
We've sketched at the Flatiron Plaza and Madison Square Park a lot, partly because of all the great art they exhibit. There's a really amazing work of sculpture/architecture up now, by Teresita Fernández, that covers the paths with reflective leaf ceilings. It shouldn't be missed. And while we're there we can draw the Flatiron building, the other skyscrapers, the fountain, the other sculptures, the Shake Shack, and all the other sights in this busy thriving park.

We'll meet at the Flatiron Plaza, which is the area with tables just north of 23rd street, between 5th Avenue and Broadway.

Any problems on the day of the event, I can be reached at [masked]. 


Looking forward to sketching with you!

What makes our Meetups different from other art groups and classes? There's no instruction, but we like to share our work, and chat and be inspired. Share tips and learn from people in a casual environment where all levels of artists are welcome! Don't be shy to ask anyone anything!

• We sketch for a bit, usually 45 minutes or so, and then get back together and share our drawings, and then sketch again, etc. There's usually time for 3 or 4 sketches.

• Please bring your own supplies - anything you like to work with - pens, pencil, watercolor, pastel, small sketchbook or large paper, iPad, whatever suits you.

• We hand out nametags so everyone can meet one another!

• We take photos to share on the site later. Bring your camera!

• Please take care to make sure we do not leave any trash behind. Please also leave any dogs at home; they tend to knock over the artwork. Thanks. 

• This Meetup is FREE and everyone at all skill levels is welcome!

In case of rain, I will let people know early in the morning if it is canceled, and then reschedule for another day.

How does the Wait List work? If the event is full, rsvp to be added to the Wait List. If someone from the regular list cancels, the first person on the Wait List is automatically bumped up to regular attendee.

Please note that if you add a comment below it will spam everyone with an email, so please use your judgement.

results.description:
This week we continue our discussion of the Seven Factors of Awakening and look at the factor of TRANQUILITY.

In our discussions so far, we've looked at MINDFULNESS, INVESTIGATION, ENERGY and JOY that are energetic, positive qualities. With TRANQUILITY the list continues with factors that are more calming in nature. Although many of us come to meditation looking for peace and tranquility, it is important to look at TRANQUILITY as a part of the full recipe of awakening factors and not an end in itself. All of the factors work together and in practice we lean toward finding balance among them. 

This understanding of tranquility is also not the peace and calm we imagine we'll get if we deny or push away any disturbances of thoughts and actions we don't like. It’s the deeper and fuller experience of tranquility we can know regardless of what life throws at us - "a tranquil frame of mind even when soaked to the skin."

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 but whatever you offer is greatly appreciated and no one is ever turned away for lack of funds. The donation box in on the Sign-in table.

Meditation Facilitator: John Hertel, MA is a Brooklyn-based, NYU-certified executive coach and long-time meditator. Meditation instruction is presented in safe and relaxed environments suitable for practitioners at any level. John also brings many years of senior management experience and a Master's degree from Columbia University in Educational Psychology.There are Seven Factors of Awakening in Buddhism.

•  Mindfulness 

• Investigation 

• Energy 

• Joy

•Tranquility 

• Concentration 

• Equanimity


The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.
results.name: The Seven Factors of Awakening - Tranquility

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Ensemble class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome!

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."

results.description:
I am a therapist, divorce mediator, and adjunct professor at NYU with a specialization in eating disorders. I am interested in helping to facilitate a monthly meet-up group to discuss experiences, treatment options, and helpful ideas in dealing with eating disorders of all types. I have years of experience treating bulimia, binge eating, anorexia, and issues of body image, with excellent results.


In addition to seeing patients individually for eating disorders (among other issues), I'm currently forming an ongoing, weekly therapy group for persons with eating disorders who are looking for something more ongoing and intensive. I work on a sliding fee scale, so I will do what I can to make it work for you. My approach is a combination of psychodynamic, cognitive-behavioral, and Buddhist principles, with a healthy dose of compassion and understanding!

Our meetups are held in Union Square, near 12th Street and University Place.

Please give me a call or email me if you think you might be interested in attending the meet-ups or in learning more about individual or group therapy. Space is somewhat limited, so if you are interested, it's best to call or email me right away.


Thank you!


Judie Stein, Ph.D., L.M.S.W.
Director
Stein Mediation & Family Center


(212)[masked]

results.description:
Hey Alumni members!

Our friends at the Liberty Humane Society are having a great fundraising event and they've asked us to help out with pictures.

Here's a description of the event from LIS's web site:

"Bark in the Park, Liberty Humane's biggest fundraising and alumni gathering event of the year, is back! To celebrate Bark in the Park’s 12th year, we are planning for an even bigger and better event at Stevens Park in Hoboken that will be jam-packed with fun games for humans and their furry friends. The event kicks off with the Walk-n-Wag Fundraiser that concludes at Stevens Park for the Bark In The Park festival, full of vendors, contests, games, crafts, demonstrations, and more!"

So let's show up, shoot pictures of dogs and their owners, have a bunch of fun, and help a great cause.

We are doing a good service for them by donating our time, if you would like to do more you are welcome to here: BARK IN THE PARK.


I hope to see you there.


-Craig

F train to York St.

results.description:
Have you ever dreamed about biking or walking over the Verrazano?

Since the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was built more than 50 years ago, elected officials and community leaders from both Brooklyn and Staten Island have called for a connecting path for people on foot and on bike. Now, thanks to a current construction project, New York has the chance to make this long-awaited path a reality!

Show Up
Join Transportation Alternatives and the Harbor Ring Committee at the foot of the bridge as we rally in support of building a pedestrian and bicycling path on the Verrazano. Join elected officials and community leaders as one voice and demand access to the landmark span in our backyard.

results.description:
Now celebrating its 53rd year, the New York Film Festival—running Sep 25–Oct 11—highlights the best in world cinema, featuring premieres, newly restored classics, special events, filmmaker talks, and more. 

The New York Film Group is pleased to support the Film Society of Lincoln Center's special event HBO Directors Dialogues: Todd Haynes

This event is an intimate conversation with director Todd Haynes at this year’s NYFF, with a focus on his filmmaking practice. A genuinely independent filmmaker, Todd Haynes has an impressive body of work that is grounded in the pressures of conformity, bearing down on individuals and sometimes resulting in illness (Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story, Safe) or other forms of entrapment (Far from Heaven, Mildred Pierce), sometimes in transcendence (Velvet Goldmine, I’m Not There). WithCarol, his remarkable new adaptation of Patricia Highsmith’s The Price of Salt, Haynes has given us a delicately nuanced work about the slowly evolving romance between two women in 1950s America, and found a reverberant emotionalism with his actors (Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara) and his cinematographer (the great Ed Lachman) that is a wonder to behold. 


The event will take place on October 10th at 12:00pm, Lincoln Center - Francesca Beale Theater – To find this theater, walk to the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center (144 W 65th Street, south side between Broadway & Amsterdam), which holds the Francesca Beale Theater and is easier to find by that name. This is a free event, but is on a first come basis, so please arrive early to the box office!

HBO Directors Dialogues: Todd Haynes | NYFF

The New York Film Group will continue hanging out and networking after the event at PJ Clarke's by Lincoln Center at 2:00 pm - 44 West 63rd Street. http://www.pjclarkes.com/lincoln-square/.

We look forward to seeing you there!

TJ Collins

NYFG Co-Founder & Organizer

www.newyorkfilmgroup.com 


www.facebook.com/Newyorkfilmgroup
results.name: HBO Directors Dialogues: Todd Haynes - Free event!

Greenwood is one of the world's most beautiful cemeteries, with lovely landscaping, rolling hills, tranquil ponds, and amazing monuments--a veritable outdoor sculpture museum, and final home of Leonard Bernstein and numerous other luminaries. 

PLEASE READ THE DETAILS BELOW, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED, ESPECIALLY FOR LUNCH:

DISTANCE: 3-4 miles.

PACE: MODERATE (2.5 MPH), NOT SLOW.  PLEASE, IF YOU WANT TO WALK SLOWLY, THIS IS NOT THE RIGHT EVENT FOR YOU. 

ENDING TIME: Around 5 PM. But you can leave earlier, of course.

LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll start eating at around 2:30 PM.


COST: $5 to Greenwood plus $2 to me, in  part to cover Meetup's organizer fee.

TRANSPORTATION: R train to 25th St. For more details, consult hopstop.com, mta.tripplanner.org, or both, since each is occasionally inaccurate.


WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient, no matter how many are waiting. Wait lists can shrink fast because of cancellations, especially at the last minute. And you can come if you're in the top 20 on the list (shown below the main list on the right side of this page on a computer--not an app or mobile device) at any time before the walk starts. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up.

results.description:
Let’s explore how the Civil War impacted lower Manhattan on this fact-filled walk. Hear tales of the Draft Rioters that attacked Newspaper Row and threatened the financial institutions of Wall Street; the Copperheads that continued to aid the Confederate cause, whether overtly or covertly; the last-ditch effort of a determined band of Confederate arsonists to create a panic in New York City; and the grieving multitudes that turned out as the coffin of the martyred Abraham Lincoln lay in state at City Hall itself.  Add even more stories about opinionated diarist George Templeton Strong, shrewd impresario PT Barnum, silver-tongued politician Fernando Wood, and even the infamous Boss Tweed on our journey back to the Civil War era downtown.


Where to meet:  inside the gates of Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street. On the uptown side, there is a whitish canopy with seating; meet us there.

When to meet: 12:45 for a 1pm start. I will be holding a sign that reads, "Civil War Downtown". 

Train: Take the 4,5 to "Wall Street" and you're right in front of Trinity Church; take the R to "Rector Street" and you're right in back of Trinity Church.

Fee: $20 cash, $15 for seniors 65 + with proof of age; exact change appreciated! Please bring bills, not coins.  Sorry, please do not bring dogs or minor children age 17 or below on the tours.

The tour will be approximately 2.5 hours long. For sunny days, be sure to bring a hat and a bottle of water. Check the weather reports on the day of the tour; if there is a chance of rain, please bring your own umbrella.  While Friendly Native tours usually do take place on the date and at the time they are scheduled, on occasion they will be postponed in cases of high temperatures or high probability of rain,  and an email sent out to that effect to all who have registered for the event.

The nearest restrooms to this location are inside Trinity Church itself. Enter the church and walk all the way to the back. Please be sure to "take care of things" before the start of the tour!
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be holding a sign reading CIVIL WAR DOWNTOWN
results.name: The CIVIL WAR in DOWNTOWN MANHATTAN

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
